instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
As soon as I plug in the charger it goes green and turns orange and won't start, with or without the battery connected.
  Apparently it doesn't have any charred resistors.
  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.6V

<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> pins:

1 - 16.5v
12 - 3.3v
14 - 3v

The others I will measure tomorrow.

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> works.
Good enough to check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS and <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS and <SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> are present
17/18 =  3.5 Ohms
27/28 = 20 Ohms

The funny thing is that when I individually measure the resistors <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> they present their resistance correctly.
Am I doing something wrong?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
The funny thing is that when I individually measure the resistors <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> they present their resistance correctly.
  Am I doing something wrong?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
The values reported are correct.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message: Yes, I have 3.42V and as soon as I activate the power <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> falls too!

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message: Ok, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
I do not have the pulse <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> , is with 0V and when I press the power it stays the same.
 I don’t have a short on that line.

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
Seems to have a PCH related problem.

Post <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC signals.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> =  3.2v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.03V ( <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> is with 10k correctly )
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =  3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> =  3.2v

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.03V"
Are you using ORIGINAL 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
I’m using a parallel charger from the client itself, but I tried an original 45W and now I’m using it straight from the asymmetric source and all point to the same result of 0.3V
  On the other side of the resistance I have the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but passes only 0.3V but the resistance is with its normal value of 10K, is some PCH instruction and or SMC informing that the battery is low!
  Can this be caused by corrupted BIOS?
 
[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD][/TD]

[TD][/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message: One thing I noticed, is that when plugging the charger, the resistance of the side of <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes at 200 Ohms and when I shoot the charger, back to 0 Ohms. I also noticed that there is a <TRANSISTOR>Q3000</TRANSISTOR> reference transitor that is connected to this line, maybe it may be causing this problem, i’m not very convinced, but I’m already desperate, so...

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
"Are you using ORIGINAL [U][B]60/85W[/B][/U] Magsafe 2 charger?
----------------------
I tried an original [U][B]45W[/B][/U]"
Can you test with original [U][B]60[/B][/U], or [U][B]85W[/B][/U] Magsafe 2 charger???


"I’m using it straight from the asymmetric source"
Using 60/85W Magsafe 2 cable for sure???


"when plugging the charger, the resistance of the side of <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes at 200 Ohms"
STOP checking in diode mode, or ohm scale on powered board!!!

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
I don't have an original 60 or 85W charger, it will take a while to arrive if I order 1 for testing. From the tests I did on other macbooks, with the asymmetric font, I didn't have similar problems, I don't think it's the font, but I'll follow your instructions!
  Is there anything else I can check until the charger arrives?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
The board should turn on with 45W charger if battery is connected and holds some charge.
It may also turn on in SMC bypass mode.

PCH requires high level on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> to start power on sequence in normal mode.

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message: Do you think that while I wait for the load, I can do something like, reset the BIOS, or would it be a waste of time?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message:
I suggested you to try SMC bypass.

Is the battery charging?

threads.title: Apple Macbook Pro Retina 13/ MB: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / The green LED lights up and then goes to orange and does not turn on
threads.message: Do not understand, how to do the SMC bypass process?
